messageBody:
Hi Pico,

To use junit effectively, you need to understand that it has its
limitation in what it can test and that it depends on our building our
classed to be 'testable'. The testablility of classes is an important
aspect during our design and development phase.

If you have some method that modifies a private variable, unless an
external entity (your junit tester) can see that change, there is no
way we can test its value.


Sarath.



On Thu, 10 Feb 2005 10:33:29 +0000, Andrew McDonagh
<andrew.mcdonagh@...> wrote:
> Pico Geyer wrote:
>
> >Hi
> >
> >I'm a little confused on how to test certain types of methods.
> >Is JUnit supposed to be able to test all types of methods.
> >
> >For example how do you test a:
> >1) Method that only modifies private fields and has no corresponding
> >getter method to see if the field is now at the correct value
> >
> >
>
> There must be some form of change in the system, aside from the internal
> private fields being modified, use this to verity the public method
> worked as expected.
>
> >2) Methods that work on network traffic, ex counting all TCP packets
> >that I receive. I would need an isolated environment and would need to
> >be able to send X amount of packets to my machine.
> >
> >
>
> This is where MockObjects come into play.
